keyTakeAways: Dozens of people were killed in a fuel tanker explosion in Niger state, Nigeria, after the vehicle skidded off the road and spilled fuel.
Villagers collected spilled fuel from the overturned tanker, leading to an explosion and massive fire that burned victims beyond recognition.
At least 35 people were reported dead, with 40â€“42 injured, according to different sources including the Federal Road Safety Corps and Nema.
The accident occurred near Essan and Badeggi communities on the Bida-Agaie road in Katcha Local Government Area, Niger state.
Poor road conditions are cited as a key factor in the tanker crash, which is common in Nigeria due to deteriorating infrastructure.

This incident is part of a larger pattern of tanker explosions in Nigeria, including a deadly explosion in Jigawa state last October that killed 153 people and a previous incident in Suleja in January 2025 that killed 86.
Despite repeated public awareness campaigns, local communities continue to collect fuel from spilled tanker contents, demonstrating a failure in safety education and enforcement.
Niger State Governor Mohammed Umaru Bago condemned the incident, calling it 'worrisome, unfortunate and pathetic' and criticizing people's continued risky behavior despite warnings.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A fuel tanker explosion in Niger state, Nigeria, killed at least 35 people and injured over 40 others after the vehicle skidded off the Bida-Agaie road and spilled fuel. Villagers collected the spilled fuel, leading to an immediate explosion and massive fire. The incident occurred near Essan and Badeggi communities in the Katcha Local Government Area and is linked to poor road conditions. This tragedy reflects a recurring pattern in Nigeria, with similar disasters occurring in Jigawa state in October 2024 and Suleja in January 2025. Despite repeated public awareness campaigns, communities continue to engage in dangerous fuel collection, highlighting a failure in public safety education and infrastructure management. Governor Mohammed Umaru Bago and officials from the National Emergency Management Agency (Nema) and Federal Road Safety Corps responded to the incident, underscoring both local and national concerns about road safety and fuel handling risks.
title: Nigeria tanker explosion: Dozens killed scooping fuel in Niger state
